body:
While Movement's home base is Hart Plaza, plenty of the best electronic music action will be happening in clubs, bars and makeshift party spots all over Detroit throughout the weekend.
Here are 10 of the best afterparties and related events. For even more options, check out the list at the Movement website.
Matthew Dear Open to Close: Many Movement parties are defined by long lists of performers. But a 9-hour solo set by a producer-musician-DJ? That's unusual. This Matthew Dear event is an opportunity to see a maestro at work. 10 p.m. Friday-6 a.m. Saturday, Leland City Club, 400 Bagley Ave., Detroit. 313-962-2300. $10-$25.
Soul Skate: Mahogani Music’s biannual skating party attracts world-class roller skaters and techno DJs for a night at the rink. Featuring DJ Soulnificent and DJ Arson. 11 p.m. Saturday-5 a.m. Sunday, Northland Roller Rink, 22311 W. 8 Mile Rd., Detroit. 313-535-1666. $15.
Soul Clap’s House of Efunk: The spectrum of beats, rhymes and funk rhythms ranges from an all-45-inch DJ set by Biz Markie to performances by Amp Fiddler, Soul Clap, Norm Talley and Overdub. 10 p.m. Saturday-noon Sunday. TV Lounge, 2548 Grand River Ave., Detroit. $20-$30.

Detroit Love: Carl Craig brings his world-touring Detroit Love concept to his hometown. He also headlines this event that includes DJs Dubfire, Seth Troxler and Keith Kemp. 11 p.m.-4 a.m. Saturday, Masonic Temple, 500 Temple St., Detroit. $25.

Tresor 25 Years: The influential Berlin-based Tresor imprint and club has deep Detroit ties, reflected in this DJ lineup of Berliners and Detroiters. Performers include Moritz von Oswald, Regis, Dasha Rush, Mike Parker, Silent Servant, Terrence, DJ Stingray, Claude Young and Anthony (Shake) Shakir. 10 p.m. Saturday-6 a.m. Sunday, Hastings Street Ballroom, 715 E Milwaukee St., Detroit. $28.
30th Anniversary of Transmat: The iconic Detroit record label celebrates three decades with a lineup that includes label founder Derrick May, the godfather of techno Juan Atkins and Salar Ansari. 10 p.m. Saturday-5 a.m. Sunday, Museum of Contemporary Art Detroit, 4454 Woodward Ave., Detroit. $35.

Experience Submerge 2016: Submerge is both a techno museum and music mecca, and will feature listening sessions of talents including DJ Scurge, John Collins and Ray 7. Limited seating, 2-4:30 p.m. Saturday and Sunday, 3000 E. Grand Blvd., Detroit. Free.
Electric Tribe: A hard-hitting lineup that includes techno innovator Kevin Saunderson, Green Velvet, Gene Farris, Dantiez and Bejelo. 11 p.m. Sunday-4 a.m. Monday, Populux, 4120 Woodward Ave., Detroit. $15.
No Way Back: The annual party is a reunion for Detroit techno insiders past and present including BMW, Carlos Souffront, Erica, Patrick Russell, Mike Servito, Derek Plaslaiko, Bryan Kasenic, Scott Zacharias, John Elliott and Nihal Ramchandani, 11 p.m. Sunday-10 a.m. Monday. Tangent Gallery, 715 E. Milwaukee, Detroit. $28.
Ain’t No Party Like a Detroit Party ’Cause a Detroit Party Don’t Stop: The all-star lineup includes Speedy J, Octave One, John Acquaviva and Doc Martin. A portion of the ticket proceeds benefit the Flint Water Fund, Bert's Warehouse's Feeding the Homeless and Detroit Public School’s Foundation charities. 9 p.m. Sunday-6 a.m. Monday, Bert’s Warehouse, 12739 Russell St., Detroit. $50.
headline: Movement afterparties: 10 top events during fest weekend

photo.caption: Detroit-based electronic musician Matthew Dear performs at the Grasshopper Underground in Ferndale on Friday, Feb. 19, 2016.
photo.credit: John Froelich, Special to the Free Press

subheadline: Detroit will be pulsating with electronic music and dance parties throughout Memorial Day Weekend
summary: For even more options, check out the list at the Movement website.
Soul Skate: Mahogani Music’s biannual skating party attracts world-class roller skaters and techno DJs for a night at the rink.
A portion of the ticket proceeds benefit the Flint Water Fund, Bert's Warehouse's Feeding the Homeless and Detroit Public School’s Foundation charities.
